description: Coined c. 1881, as a diminutive of triskeles, specifically in numismatics to refer to minuscule forms of the symbol found on ancient coins. No direct derivation from Katharevousa τρισκέλιον (triskélion, “three-legged stool; rule of three, analogy”).

entries.meaning: A figure composed of three interlocked spirals (or three bent human legs), with threefold rotational symmetry.
examples: Sicily and the Isle of Man use triskelia as their emblems.
